description.text:
The Fabtotum has some real issues with putting the Bowden feeder's PTFE tubes in harms way, resulting in crushed tubes, increased friction and broken filament. One way of alleviating this issue is to run the printer with the back of the Fabtotum removed. This seems to allow the tubes to flex out of the way of the moving Z-Axis.  
One issue with removing the back panel is that the power socket module containing the power socket and power switch are snapped and glued onto the back panel. You can remove the this module and run it this way, but I thought a cleaner approach might be to build a mini plate to hold the module in place as well as allowing slots for the existing ventilation, USB and Ethernet ports.  
This is what I came up with. It is not nicely curved on the bottom as the Fabtotum's original back panel, nor is it pretty, but it works reasonably well. It probably does not matter, but I have made the ventilation holes larger and better aligned with the fan.  
The OpenSCAD source is included for easy remixing if somebody wants to try and build that nice curve, or if the European model is different.  
I printed this on the Fabtotum, having the fab slice it using the Draft setting.  
Note this uses the bottom screw hole that the original back panel uses, but not the top one. Instead there is a screw hole in the middle that is used. This prevents the left side panel from fitting properly, so I just run without it.

• Print the mini back panel and clean up any strings or lumpy bits with a sharp hobby knife. I had plastic slumped into the screw holes so I had to drill out the two screw holes to clean them up. The holes are 3.3mm so choose a 1/8" drill bit.
  • Turn off the fabtotum and unplug the mains power at the wall and at the fabtotum.
  • Remove the Fabtotum rear panel according to instructions in the Fabtotum forum.
  • There are 3 wires that plug into the power block. Make a note or take a photo of which wire goes where. Unplug the 3 wires from the power block.
  • The power block is glued to the back panel and has wings that you will need to compress. Pry the power block on one end while compressing the wings. Clean up any glue/plastic remnants on the power block.
  • Push the power block into the Mini Back Panel. The wings should expand to hold it. The power switch was originally at the bottom, but you could turn it upside down to have the power switch at the top.
  • Fit the Mini Back Panel onto the Fabtotum and screw it the bottom screw and a screw about half way up. I reused the screws from the top and bottom of the original back panel.

description.text:
Instead of having to undo screws, use these snap in spool holders to quickly change spools on your Solidoodle printer.  I have uploaded both 1.25in and 1in rod holders. And this will make changeing spools very fast.  The snap in action is secure and unlikely to ever pop out on its own, even while moving the machine.  
Enjoy!

Print 1 each of the Left and Right spool holders for the desired axle size.  Then print 2 each of the small and long brackets, screw together with #6 coarse thread or appropriate screws for your area.  Load axel up with 1 or more spools and snap into place.

title: Hexapod "Gilbert300" : Arduino Mega 2560 based 3d printed 6 legs robot

description.text:
Here is the last version of my 3D printed PLA hexapod : Gilbert300.
Watch its first walk :
http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x32snjf_2015-08-23-gilbert300-first-walk_tech The body :
  • 2 main plates naed "body-V2" and "body-V2-upérieur"
  • 6 x "entretoise-V2"
  • 1 "support_ubec_fan_switch"
  • 1 "deck arduino" (that support the Arduino MEGA 2560)
    • The leg (x6) :
  • 3 x "bracket servo MGR996R"
  • 2 x "fork servo MG996R"
  • 1 x "fork 45 servo MGR996R"
  • 1 x "US sensor bracket"
  • 1 x "foot with switch rotule"
  • 3 x "flange parametric"

comments.author: McKraken

comments.text: Philippe
comments.author: alanacv

comments.text:
Hi,
I made some trials connecting 7 US sensors at the same time to an Arduino Mega 2560 (without the servos). It's working quite good.
The number of ports of the Mega 2560 is enough to connect at the same time 18 servos and 6 US sensors. The only one problem is the sampling frequency of the US sensors, that may provoque an irregular gait when continuous sensing. I made the choice to sense only when leg touch-down. I did'nt connect the US sensors to Gilbert300 yet. Before that, I need to simplify the "gait" program, to facilitate the integration of the range sensing functions (i.e. using only the "wave gait" which is a googd compromise between stability, velocity and complexity).
At the present time I'm working on the connection and integration of the switches that ensure the "touch down" sensing.
Integration of US sensing on Gilbert300 function will follow after.
i will post videos as soon as the sensing is operative.
Best regards,
Philippe

remixed_from.title: Vertical Charging Stand for Original Pebble

description.text:
Fairly straight forward vertical stand for the Pebble Time, designed to allow the straps to hang downwards instead of requiring you to feed them through gaps as required in other designs.  
The charging cable is secured into the printed part with a small strip of 3M 03609 VHB tape. The wire easily pushes into the groove, and is also held in place with a few strips of the same VHB. I strongly recommend you pick a place for the stand and affix it there with some Command Adhesive strips between the bottom of the stand and the surface top; the weight of the stand is not sufficient to allow you to just pull the watch off.  
Printed on an UM2 with 0.2mm layer heights at 40 mm/s, 50% infill for structural rigidity. Support needed on the wire channel.

Fuel Door Hinge Pin for 2009 - 2014 Ford F-150.

Requires a small screw and washer to prevent the pin from popping out; something Ford should have done with the original part. If your original pin is still whole, you'll only need the screw and washer. I twisted mine in two trying to repair it, so I designed this to avoid having to buy expensive factory replacement parts.  
Ford's original design was weakened by their attempts to save plastic in manufacturing. The pivot point of the spring and the shaft are thicker in my design.

description.text: A belt tensioner for your Migbot I3. You will have to drill a hole for the adjuster screw. The screw should be an M3x30 but if you feel adventurous, you can countersink the hole and use an M3x20 screw and nut. You will also have to trim about 30mm from the timing belt to make this work.

author: HelldogAUT

description.text:
Update:
Due to some bugs in the initial version, a revision of the OpenSCAD library has been uploaded, please use "polyScrewThread_r1.scad". Thanks a lot to mechadense for reporting the bugs! This is my humble take on a screw library to be used in your OpenSCAD scripts. If you are serious, please be, you'll better use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 syvwlch. Anyway, I had this thing for months in the lost projects folder suffering from some serious issues, well some of them remain (it doesn't render) and once the dust has been shaken it compiles quite nice and printable things. Instead of functions, this thing uses loops.
Instead of rotate polyhedrons, this thing draws the polyhedron in a new set of points. Just a couple of comments to help using this thing:

  • I've found that a resolution of something like 1.5mm (PI/2 is what I use the most) works very well for threads that will be used with nuts made with a resolution of 0.5mm.

  • I've printed the threads with a very low infill (0.2) but for the nuts, setting up this value (I've used 0.45) helped a lot with the overhang issue.
    • More pics @ http://aubenc.imgur.com/screws_threads_an_other_polyhedron_games

Do not use "polyScrewThread.scad", in contains some bugs! Instead...
Drop "polyScrewThread_r1.scad" into your OpenSCAD library folder or the folder where you are writing your OpenSCAD script.
Use polytests.scad (*) as a user's guide, refference, whatever.
(* - Depending on how old/new is your OpenSCAD you may need to change the line where the library is included, replace "include" by "use")
Because this thing is made without much science, you'll need to tweak a little bit, sorry...
First print a nut (high res, see comments above), tweak the infill and/or the degrees for the shape of the thread.
Once your nut prints fine, print a short threaded rod, try to change the resolution of the thread, infill,... use your imagination.
I printed the provided examples and they all work fine without any cleaning, that's the reason why they look so ugly in the pictures.
Design bolted things.
Print bolted things.
Bolt things.
Keep on bolting!

author: Gosa

description.text: i thought it funny that the LCD board had a reset button on it but was hard to get to  when needed, so, this is a reset button i whipped up. drilling is required though. sorry for the dusty photo.

You have to remove the LCD board and measure from the control knob to the board mounted reset button (center to center). I drilled a small pilot hole first, then basically gauging the size of drill bit by eye, drilled the main hole. i mounted the LCD board in this order: screw-acrylic frame-2 washers-standoff-board-nut. i did this in the beginning because i wanted to get the mini speaker off the acrylic frame when mounting. this button is designed for this. When finished, the button barely sticks out from the frame so it will be harder to accidentally push it when making control knob adjustments.

comments.text: yeah, i thought it was kind of stupid to provide a reset button but no way to get to it unless you used a popsicle stick. lol

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Fan Cover & Hose Clamp

description.text:
I designed a fan cover for "safety" purposes and thought I'd integrate a hose clamp in order to route wiring as well as reduce flex near the extruder motor. The clamp will form a second secure point other than the zip-tie beneath the extruder motor. Fan size: 40x40mm
Clamp inner diameter: 10mm
Cover only: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:879894 The fan cover uses the existing screws and the thread is just long enough to exit the hex nut. This is the case when using 50an6xy06r6n's fan duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356001)
or my remix thereof (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878681). And NOT the standard Pribtrbot fan shroud. It is a tight squeeze to get the wiring and wire wrap into the clamp, but that is the point.
Install:
1) Remove approximately 5cm (2 inches) of the wire wrap.
2) Get all the wiring within the clamp.
3) Slide the clamp forward and over the wire wrap by sliding an extended piece of wire wrap through the clamp opening.
4) Once the clamp is over the wire wrap, reinstall the wire wrap.
5) Slide the clamp backwards over the reinstalled wire wrap.
6) Assemble the fan cover, fan and fan shroud.
7) Tighten clamp with zip-tie. (2.5mm wide zip-tie)

I printed with 50% infill, mainly to keep the clamp arm rigid.
0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness.
PLA @ 25mm/s @ 208degC.
No support needed, steepest angle from vertical is approximately 56 degrees.

author: Bob_Ferr

title: Full utilisation of PCB heatbed build area

description.text:
If you have the Reprap PCB heatbed (http://reprap.org/wiki/PCB_Heatbed) you are most likley using a piece of 200mm x 200mm glass as a build platform. You will soon realise, if you have not already, that it is rather difficult to print an object that requires the full 200 x 200 build area. This is my solution to the problem. It involves a piece of glass cut to the same size as the PCB with provision made for the mounting holes, as well as small printed place holders but there are not necessary.
The place holders go on the 4 corners of the print bed and hold the glass in position. They are made only 3 mm high, the same as the glass thickness, to prevent and accedental extruder crash.

Get a piece of 3mm float glass cut to 214mm x 214 mm with 14mm chamfers cut off the corners, this is to make provision for the holes. See diagram.
Print out 4 of the corner pieces. Theses are to assist in keeping the glass in position but note that you will most likely still require binder clips to hold the glass down firmly.

My usual over engineered bolted togetherness has given way to some more milder engineered bolted togetherness, and I am sure this will offend so many people, but it works for me and I thought I'd share. You will need a handlebar tripod mount that will hold the go-pro mount, or a small camera, it's the standard small 1/4 inch type. You can pick them up on Amazon for £2.99, or a more branded or heavy duty version for £7.99. There is no button to press, so this may aggravate you, however I run my watch "always on" so never use the button, and if I have to on the bike, the pin does stick out enough to get a nail to it. 2015-07-04 EDIT - Version 2 added
I am leaving the original files in here because I think it's still a nice design, but I have taken a lot of feedback from some cycling buddies and redesigned accordingly:
  • Only one bolt now. 4 was way too finicky and meant you needed to set up off bike, now you can leave the base attached and add the watch in only a few seconds.
  • The bolt threaded end was little too long and got to the end of the channel without tightly gripping the frame so I've taken off a couple of layers.
  • The bolt head was a little too short and you'd struggle in the cold or in gloves. Added 2.5mm.
  • The base can be mounted "bolt up" or "bolt down" depending on your preference.
  • Still no access to the charging hole, it's much easier to take the watch out, and if you need to walk away from the bike for any reason.
  • Still no button presser for simplicity, "Always on" seems to be fine.

Which base you need depends. If you happen to have a spare standard quarter inch whitworth or UNC nut to hand, then print out the bolt-on base for the nut. You glue the nut in and you don't have to worry about shearing the plastic so much. Should you not have anything designed in the 19th century to hold steam engines together to hand you can print out the standard screw-on base. It should be strong enough to handle all but a large tumble off the bike, and in this event the case should fail to absorb as much energy so you don't break your watch. I've printed mine at 3 shells and 25% infill and it's plenty strong enough. The new Version 2
You only need one bolt and the top printing out. The Original Version 1
You will need 4 bolts and one top printing out.

title: Travel Case for E-flite or Tiny Whoop 1S Batterys

description.text:
I am going to be traveling soon so I wanted a case that would meet the TSA requirement that all batteries had to be isolate from each other so that the contacts can not touch each other, or other batteries.  I designed this case to fit that bill.  Can double as general transport and storage for the eflite batteries.  
Update: I have recently returned from a trip out of country where I used this case.  I got through TSA as well as the foreign countries security on the way back without issue.  Also of note, I printed out the official lipo travel rules.  I can not guarantee what your experiences with TSA will be,  use this at your own risk.  I will say if you do the research and know the rules and can answer questions correctly and with authority when asked things go a lot smoother.  
As for the print itself, The lid slides on pretty well and its pretty snug,  you may need to sand it to get a good fit.  You also might need to sand down the locking nub,  by default it held a little too aggressive with my print but quickly solved by sanding it down a little.  I printed mine at 20% infill and support, however with the fillets that I used, it may actually print well without support.  If you print it, let me know what settings you used and what results you got.  Share some pictures and your feedback.
Update 1/27/17:  I added a new version "Holder_WhoopExtended.STL" which is extended in length and has larger relief pockets for the larger "PowerWhoop" PH2.0 connector.  This is the photo using the Blue PETG filament in my photos.  The batteries shown are 250mAh "HV" cells.  The lid is compatible with both version.

comments.text: Had to make it taller to accommodate the 205mah batts. Works excellent.

comments.text: Beware I had a friend print this and his aftermarket batteries didn't fit (height was too short). I think it's a great design, but please note that if you don't check your height of the largest battery against the internal storage height, you're going to waste 10-12 hours of printing! My friend doesn't draft, so I had to import the .stl, stretch it up to 2 5/8" total height (67.46mm), and send it to him.

title: Steampunk Zelda Wind Fish Moai/Tiki Statue/Sculpture/Bust

description.text:
Hello everyone, I am back, and I have helped make this statue. It is a remix of Dimetrii/tbuser's tiki statue, and dutchmogul's steamed fish. I left the internal geometry untouched so you can see both statues using mesh lab's X-ray shader. I made it using mesh lab's merge tool, and luck on position data. The fish looks like Zelda's Wind Fish, and the moai appears to sit down in a throne. This would make a great bookend or wall decoration, provided it gets 3d printed. I do not mean any offense to anyone in making this. I used collada as it is very flexible, plus I can put comments inside to give info about the model, its open-source license, and a message saying to credit me (if I wanted to.)  
Sincerely, stgiga  
Credit goes to Dimetrii of Blendswap, dutchmogul, and tbuser.
Meshlab's Merge tool, with a bit of position data fiddling.

comments.author: SK-Polymer

comments.text: Yes, but only in Spain. RationalStock.es
comments.author: SK-Polymer

description.text: Left and Right mounts for the Afinia 3d Printer that hold Superbright LED Bar's to light the print surface / extruder.

I bought an Afinia 3d printer and I found myself holding a flashlight to see my extruder nozzle to level the bed, and of course to watch it print. I also had a few of these super bright LED "light bars" left over from a MAME cabinet build I did. So I made these "mounts" in Google Sketch up to hold the light bars so they illuminate the entire 3d print area. No more holding the flashlight! I connected the LEDs to a leftover 12 volt wall-wart power adapter I had and used double-sided 3m stick tape to mount them to the holder. Not gorgeous by any stretch, but I'm new to sketch up and I wanted it done asap, and so here we are! Regardless. I LOVE the end result. They fit using the existing screws that are on the top left and right sides of the printer. The LED's I used were these:
http://groovygamegear.com/webstore/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=83&products_id=307

comments.text: Good work keep it up
Thanks much!  :)

title: Battery holder for 250 quadcopter - Diatone and Ghost Editions

description.text:
This frame mounts to the Diatone style quad frames. Drew it up to fit my Ghost Edition version. It will probably easily fit other frames as well.  
It fits my batteries which range from 1000mAh to 1600mAh.  
Slip some velcro strip through the slots in the side to fix the battery into the holder.  
"Batt 1" is more of a solid object with a couple holes in the base for using less plastic and lightening it up.  
"Batt 2" has some slots through the edges to lessen stresses and hopefully lower the chances of warping during printing. I printed mine in ABS with this file since ABS is strong but tends to warp.   
"Spacer" is a small washer which I needed so the holder would not smash against the innermost LEDs on the bottom. Just print 4 and slip them between the holder and the frame when installing if you need them.

description.text: This is a case for the FG085 miniDDS function generator made by JYE Tech and sold through a number of different channels. See http://www.jyetech.com/Products/085/e08503K.php for a description. The case is for the "panelled" version, which contains a nicely made and labelled front panel, but nothing for the sides, top nor bottom. This design does not use the supplied rear panel. Note that this case is made for the current panels, with a small angle in the sides. Early panels had straight side edges, and I am not sure if these will fit. Also, note there are other cases for FG085 on Thingiverse. As for the FG085 signal generator unit itself, it should be said that it has many features, and is quite intuitive to operate. The output signal is useful for many purposes, but it is in no way perfect. Considering the cost of the unit, it is acceptable, I'd say. One issue is that there is a rather signficant jitter on the duty cycle for non-sine waveforms. There is also quite a bit of hf noise on the sinewave. Since there is no proper attenuator, low amplitude signals are really not that great, and you should probably use an external attenuator for that.
Should build without support. Since the walls are quite thick, it makes sense to build with thin shell thickness (e.g. 0.7mm) and low infill ratio (e.g. 15%). The case will still be strong.

author: m_zapp

description.text:
I had a need for a simple and robust tilt solution. So i designed this to do the job.
The base plate is designed to hinge the camera actuator, and to house a futaba S3114 servo. The arm between the servo horn and camera actuator has a length of 15 mm. I fitted it to the hole with the cut-out area in the pillar on the base plate. This gives me from horizontal to -45 degrees to control. I redesigned the camera actuator plate because the first design wan't strong enough and able to fit small tie-wraps. This design should be able to withstand all forces. My idea was to create a flexible platform which fits multiple cameras. The actuator plae consists of small rectangles which should fit small tie-wraps. I'm going to use it to film on a airplane and quadcopter. The transmitter module that is visible in the picture, and where I designed the baseplate for is a Skyzone 200MW, RC805. I think it is very much like a Boscam TS 351.

I printed it 2 times. The first time over with 0,2 layer thickness and 3 perimeters;
The second time I printed the camera actuator with 0,3 layer thickness and 3 perimeters. The hinges have a 3.5mm hole and are designed for m3 metric bolts, but I found a tie-wrap lighter and easier. It is designed to be mounted with tie-wraps.

author: butchooka

title: Motorcycle Screw in Oil Funnel ADAPTER

description.text: M20 x 1.5 adapter for mrPens Screw in oil funnel http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:857406 Rather than modify an already great model to fit a friends Bandit 1200 I thought I'd have a go at this adapter. Wasn't too difficult until I tried to maintain breather functionality due to the much smaller size but did succeed in the end. May do other sizes if required just give me thread dia, pitch and a little time :) Added M24 x 1.5 (no bike to test thread on) 14/06/15 Updated M20 version just to give clearer breather way (could clog a little depending on print quality) 13/05/17 Added M18 x 1.5 for a request 02/06/17 Added M27 x 3.0 for a request. 12/06/17 Added M27 x 3.0 Adaptor_EXTENDED 19/08/17 Added M20 x 2.5 Please Note that depth of this thread may weaken part Again I have nothing to test thread on...

The first thread or so of outside thread should break off pretty easily, I put a cut around it to help this.  This was intended so that it could be printed a little easier either way up and when finished the inside tube would be raised above the thread.  
In the top of the adapter is a tube with a chamfer, this is where the funnel will seal against the adapter.  
I've used PLA as I have very little joy with ABS. I imagine ABS to be better for this but have no Idea how it will affect thread size.  
After slicing make sure breather channels etc don't  break out anywhere they shouldn't and adjust slicer if necessary.  
Be very careful screwing into bike to avoid cross-threading and only a few threads are needed. The M20 thread is longer than originally planned but the extra length stopped funnel fouling on the Bandits side panel

author: jtenkely

description.text:
This is a double spool holder for the Printrbot Simple Metal.  Ever had problems switching spools on a traditional spool holder?  Hate having to juggle spools mid-way through a print?  These problems and more are solved by this Double Spool Holder!  
It can be used with the Printer Simple Metal 3D printer with the metal handle -or- without the metal handle (see images.)

For Simple Metal with metal handle, print: 1x handle_mount
2x holder_arm Slide the handle_mount over the handle and place the two arms in the square holes as shown in the picture. Place spools on the arms. ======== Or ========= For Simple Metal without metal handle, print: 1x prong_mount
2x holder_arm Slide the prong_mount onto the two vertical rails and place the two arms in the square holes as shown in the picture. Place spools on the arms. NOTE: The mount should fit tightly on either the handle or the prongs. If the mount does not fit tightly, you will need to alter you settings or modify the file. This print was designed for a Printrbot with speeds around 80 mm/sec. Plastic printed parts may fail over time. Use at you own risk.

comments.text: For the record. the spool arm on this model is the only Printrbot specific spool holder that I have come across that works with the .25lb spools  (really small) from the Makerbot Sample pack.

I designed this for the Microsoft Band.  
It is a standard that fits the magnetic loading cable. I redesigned the uploaded model to correct the flaws I noticed when I printed the first revision,  
The cable should be inserted by getting the USB plug through the rectangle at the top first. Then you try to bend the magnetic plug in so that the band holds the connection. This should be visible on the picture. In this redesign it should be easier to install and remove the plug, but i;m not sure because I did not print it.  
It may be hard to get the magnetic plug in, and even harder to get out. I use it as a permanent charging station.
I think I printed it on 0,2mm layers with 3 primeters.

title: Eiffel Tower/ Big Ben/ London Monument Hybrid.

description.text:
I lost my page, and I have to start over.
I am not happy at the web designers of this site because of this. Anyways, I have merged 3 iconic European monuments into something that the Canadians would enjoy. It is the "4-SIDE Eiffel Tower Bud Vase" by MakeALot, as the body "The Monument", also by him, as part of Big Ben and the Eiffel Tower's roof, and his "Solid Big Ben" also by him as the clock face. I made this model on December 5, 2014 before the movie Big Hero 6 came out in my local "cheap theatre" (It plays movies just before their DVD release dates), and before I had seen it or a trailer for it. The movie featured a San Francisco/ Tokyo hybrid city, with an Asian Gate/ Torii-inspired Golden Gate Bridge. I technically had created the joke in a different form (my version is Paris and London, while their version is Tokyo and San Francisco) before I knew of the film's existence aka I made the joke before they did in some case???.
Meshlab's Merge tool, and luck/being-handed-free-duplicated-position-data-on-a-silver-platter from MakeALot

My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill. Sorry for any inconvenience.

Here is a functional printable assembly of the iconic Thompson sub-machine gun. I have modelled it from machine drawings and then modified part dimensions and certain assembly tolerances so that is printable. The stock, barrel and receiver all break down into two parts which that fit together before assembly so that it can be printed on a smaller bed size. Currently, I have only posted the full assembly versions as STL's as I want to print the assembly myself before I release the files so that I know that every assembly is going to be successful so nobody is put off printing it. My end goal is to correctly size springs for the recoil and trigger mechanisms so it can be cocked and fired (obviously minus real bullets). You will also be able to add and remove the stock, have the choice of a solid or ribbed barrel, load a 20 round mag or 50 round drum and the choice of a standard sight or sight with compensator. Some of these variations can be seen in the renders. For more of my replica weapons, see my collection - https://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/replica-weapons Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases. Update - 28/09/15
STL's and SW 2012 part file uploaded. I still haven't printed this yet so please leave feedback if you have. Update - 06/11/15
Currently printing this now, will hopefully have most of it done by next week. Will post a make when completed. Update 25/11/15
Finally printed this and it looks awesome. It operates great and the trigger,safety and mag release all work as expected. Check out the images to see the result.

So, what are Bezier curves good for if you're not going to do much with them?
This thing is a simple boat created out of Bezier surfaces.  I define a bow, and a midship section, and a stern, then just stitch a few of them together.  In the picture can be seen how the control mesh looks.
This particular one shows how you have to print in a couple of halves and bring them together.  This is an artifact of the linear extrusion offered by the OpenScad bezier library.
This model takes about 3 minutes to generate the .stl from the .scad.  Not too bad.

1) Load the .stl into your favorite slicer
2) Size appropriately
3) Print
4) Rejoice! You can print in individual sections and glue together if you like. You can also change things like the width and height fairly easily, and of course, you can make it as long as you like by adding more 'midships' sections.

comments.text: Fantastic! I've been wanting to use the bezier library for ages, and this is the first example of using the library that was clear, to me at least. It's been odd - I understand the math of bezier curves, and use them all the time elsewhere, but could never figure out the parameters to DisplayBezSurface(). Thanks!
comments.author: laird

title: Articulated Robot Devil Figure from Futurama

description.text:
I am a big fan of Futurama, however I see only bunch of Benders on Thingiverse, not any other robot, so I decided to make the robot devil, the lord of the robot hell!
I drew this using Solidworks yesterday to test if I can CAD as fast as I thought I can, and the result was that I could not... I thought it would only take 2 hours but it actually took 4.5hrs.
For this model I wanted to explore some other ways to make articulated joints other than ball joints (as it is annoying that they fall off all the time), so I put some iron wires in the arms, legs and spine, and it went surprisingly well. The model can stand on its own even without the support of the tail!
Anyway that's the robot devil for you, enjoy!

Part list:
[Head]:
head
chin
eye2(white)
horn2(white)
teeth(white)
[Body]:
neck
body
universal connector as waist
hip
tail tip(iron wire as tail)
[Arms]:
universal connector6
hands
[Legs]:
universal connector6
feet instruction:
All pieces are meant to be braided with iron wires of appropriate length, at the end of the wire you can bend it into a u-shape to increase its diameter to create a tight fit, and then superglue it.

Here is a motorized lift for Tulio Laanen's excellent and popular Marble Machine 2 (Thing #795952). Derived from KreAture's Improved lift (Thing #820323)
Powered by 2 AA batteries, the lift directly retrofits and replaces the original manual lift.
https://youtu.be/Gfk6TAG3ZFM
https://youtu.be/EiT330rlnDw
edit 9Mar16: fixed lift screw, now spirals in correct direction

Print the 4 parts and clean them up. They print well without supports.
Drill out screw holes to size.
Tap the 12-tooth gear for a 6-32 setscrew.
You will need a few assorted screws to attach the battery holder and the motor cover. You will also need a short 6-32 set screw for the 12-tooth gear.
Wire the motor, switch,and battery holder. Motor is a 298:1 Micro Gearmotor from Pololu
The battery holder is Digikey BH2AA-W-ND
Switch is Digikey CWI334-ND

description.text: I made this bike mount at my good friend's request. The mount is fairly heavy duty. The estimated cost is $0.80 of ABS material at $0.02 per cc. I printed it with a honey comb structure making it strong for vertical compression. As a tip, I recommend coating the mount with epoxy for easy clean up and then paint it with a "Sharpie". Enjoy.
You will only need two bolts and two hex nuts. I used wide cap bolts [50 x 5.5mm or (2 x 0.25 in)]. I added some gaps for tolerance so if you find anything close to that you are fine.

comments.text: The angle of overhang in the build photo is crazy -- is it normal to be able to hang that far?  It looks like the rightmost strand in each layer would be hanging over open air without touching anything when it's first laid down!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: As far as the overhang goes, ABS is very sticky to itself. I drop down a little at the beginning but then it was fine. The trick is to check skeinforge layer by layer so that it would shift less than the thickens of the extrusion. As for the ceiling  of the nuts, if the space is small enough then ABS will do its thing. However at end I still had to cut some plastic out with exacto knife but only for cosmetic purpose.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Vietor, thanks for the response.
comments.author: vietor

comments.text: Imagine extruding the filling (from the picture) left to right at the lover levels. Sure some ABS "spill" over but that is the key for making such overhang. In the end the STL and the finished product are off about 1 or 2 mm so it is not such a big deal whereas ABS expand 0.25 mm any way from perfection. In addition the "fill" must be small enough zig zag or honey cone so the the wall may fall due to gravity but fill will take place and the next wall will be in better shape.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Did you model the honeycomb array in the thick sections, or is that something that the makerbot printing software will do automatically?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It was made by skeinforge software. You have to play with the fill settings for each piece

description.text: Generate a 3D model from an arbitrary source of data! This is my first attempt at an OpenSCAD script that takes an MD5 hash of a file as input and creates a unique physical object from it. OpenSCAD doesn't have a lot of string functions, so it's not quite as streamlined as that, but it's not too bad. I've written more about it at the Ponoko blog. Check it out: http://blog.ponoko.com/2011/05/25/openscad-project-files-to-physicals (The example model is created from my copy of Sea Within a Sea by The Horrors.)

• Generate an md5 hash of a file

  • Paste it into my script here to create an fp_data.scad file: http://www.obscenis.com/filestophysicals/

  • Put fp_data.scad into the same folder as the main script and compile Files to Physicals.scad

  • Export to STL

  • Print!

comments.text: This is very cool indeed.  You're basically rerendering from the abstract to the physical.  Creating a language as you go.  Of course I'm not sure there's coherance, meaning, do like things look similar, but it's obviously not necessary.  That might be an idea though.  If you reserved some number of high order bits to hold information about the kind of thing the info represents, then similar things might have a chance of taking somewhat related forms.  Pictures are corkscrews, audio files are pyramids, etc.

description.text: This new version of my Plow Horse http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40537, is split into two halves that allow printing on most machines without raft and minimal supports. The trade off is that the parts must be glued together. I use a slurry of ABS dissolved in acetone. Slight sanding of the mating surfaces may be useful. I did this modification so that the horse could be printed very small, down to HO gauge scale whereas the original was almost impossible to clean up the supports without breaking the very delicate legs.

since i had my car my gas door would always open up when i park because the ring on my lock was broken. Not anymore, i shaved the thing off and replaced it with this sturdy piece. The picture i have taken is of the broken piece and the one in sketch-up is the replacement.
PS. I know this isn't the most effective way to fix your gas door but hey! it works!

(not to replace for unbroken locks) Completely cut and shave off the little locking arm on the gas door. After doing so make sure you sand the paint off the small area where your putting it, then you can apply a industrial plastic glue/ adhesive to the end of the printed lock and place it on the proper area.

This is the dual extrusion version of my raised J-head mount.  Same pieces as before: Main mount, front piece and an air guide to help the fans direct air towards the peek barrel.   
When mounted, the J-Head nozzles should be about 8mm below the X-Carriage mounting plate. (Enough room for the head of the mounting bolt's head)  
I have printed this and have it installed.  All the measurements look good.  I added a 2nd version of the Main, the only change is I shortened the motor supports length to allow more room for the wiring to route through the rear.

Same as before: Print this with at least 40% infill and use support for the serious overhangs
Drill or ream holes to fit Hardware:
  • 2 x (20mm M5 bolt + nut + 2 washers) (I used nuts and bolts I had lying around that fit)
  • 2 x (16mm M3 machine screw) use these to screw the front plate to the main to hold the J-Heads in place.
  • 4 x (40mm M3 machine screws) these came with the qu-bd and are the right length to hold the fan mount between the front plate and the fan
  • 4 x (20mm M3 machine screw) for securing bdring's thing:38281 or mickb's thing:43411 to the top two screws on the motor
    • My software offset measurements (between the nozzles) are: X=35.2mm Y=.75mm. That should get you in the ballpark to tweak your own numbers.

I made a YouTube video showing this part in detail here: http://youtu.be/pGgKaY6h6t0
-If made correctly, this will allow breech-loading for a Nerf football launcher. This should only be used in a safe, field approved compressed air Nerf football launcher in a professionally run game of scenario paintball. It is designed to use Nerf brand Pocket Vortex and Aero Flyer foam footballs only. Do not use anything else.
-Glue a piece of 2" Sch 40 Slip (no threading) PVC for the barrel. The length of the barrel is up to you, but 2' seems to work. The compressed air comes in at a 45 degree angle from a female threaded 3/4" NPT pipe section. The loading door fits in nicely to the breech, and locks closed with a slight twist. The seal is not airtight, but does function well. I have tested this design myself, and even played with it in a game of scenario paintball.
-The height of the print should be 70.55mm when layed flat. The overhang holding the loading door on is a bit of a problem, but I printed mine without supports and only had to do a bit of cleaning. Use as much infill and layer thickness as you can, the more the better.
-This design is meant to briefly channel rushing air, not hold it. The design is not meant to support the weight of a launcher or barrel, so add a support to take the structural stress off of the printed part.

This is a sabot that is used for traditional hunting with black powder rifles. It creates a gas seal between the barrel of a muzzle loader and the bullet/Ball.
Print it. Use it, or just show it off.

comments.text: Note: This sabot accepts standard  .400" diameter bullets. I like to use hornady 10mm/.40s&w 200gr bullets. Available at any store that sells reloading supplies. Or cast you're own from bullet molds.
comments.author: inventworld

comments.text: The nice thing about ABS is any plastic fouling in your muzzle loader barrel can be easily cleaned out with acetone.  Just remember to retreat with your favorite muzzle loader bore butter or metal protectant afterwards.
comments.author: calinb

comments.text: I haven't had any issues with it yet. Seems that you standard bore brush gets it all out.
comments.author: calinb

comments.text: Have you taken any game with these yet?
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: No this year I didn't get any time to muzzleloader hunt with as much as I've been working. Hope to get the chance next year tho.
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: I am by no means a gun expert, but wouldn't an ABS or PLA sabot melt while traveling down the barrel?
comments.author: Austin

comments.text: ABS and PLA take several seconds to become molten even when exposed to high temps. In this case the contact time is about 1/100th of a second. So no problems result.
comments.author: Austin

comments.text: No it doesn't melt in the barrel and the reason is the sabot is only in contact with the hot gas an extreamly short amount of time. The factory made sabots are also made from thermoplastics and injection molded. ABS can handle some pretty harsh environments if it's only for a short amount of time. As in this case. And thanks for the comment I'm sure others were thinking the same thing.
comments.author: Austin

title: Screwball Heart Threaded Lid Pill Box Container

description.text: This is a riff on the original "screwball" container by JamieLaing (http://www.thingiverse.com/JamieLaing/designs) which can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:61205. I wanted this to be able to rest this on a tabletop without it rolling off, and I wanted to add a heart motif on the lid. I made this to hold bulk pills for my loving wife so she can keep it on her nightstand. Enjoy!

Just print it out! I printed it on a Replicator 1 in ABS with 100% fill, 1 shell, 0.15mm layers, no raft, no support. As always, I wiped ABS/acetone slurry on the bed before printing...see my Instructable at http://www.instructables.com/id/100-Warp-Free-MakerBot-3D-Printing on how to do this. Enjoy!

comments.text: I printed it at .3 layer, 20% infill and the base ended up in two parts. Used supports, but the interior wasn't very clean. Need to repeat to 100% infill as you mentioned.
comments.author: Lifeline

Parametric Rubik's Cube 3x3 (75 mm). Following parameters can be used to vary the dimensions of the cube:
size = 75.5; Needed Parts for building a single cube:
  • Each part is needed exactly once to build the cube
  • Screw M3x30 (6x)
  • Washer M3, diameter 5.8 mm (6x)
    • remark:

  • In case the "size" parameter has been changed, a different screw length will be required.

  • for a 60 mm version of this design see:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856722

• Support structures are needed to print the pieces. The STL's are positioned in the correct position to be printed.

  • 20% infill works fine.

  • It is recommended to use ABS, the assembled cube turns much smoother.

  • It is recommended to drill the small hole of the Cube_MidPiece to a diameter of 3.5 mm and the big hole to a diameter of 7.0 mm (depth = 6.5 mm).

  • It is recommended to drill the small hole of the Cube_CenterPiece to a diameter of 2.5 mm

This Case was created for HTC Desire 610 (navy Blue) but was not tested until now (my phone is for a long time on way to me...). Maybe you should resize this case with your prefered margin(dependet on your used material). Additional Note:
Second Case based on this one. Their holes are only to save some materials ;-) If you like this case, feel free to use this for other designs/prototyp... Good Luck

For Example: my printer use following resize values to fit perfect ...
... height --> X: (from bottom to PowerButton) ~100.011%
... width --> Y: (side to volume Buttons) ~100.008%
... deepth --> Z: (print ground to top) ~100.004%

author: alexbritofa

description.text: This version of the Good Samaritan has fewer moving and static parts than most of the other versions available. This should make it easier to print and assemble. The first picture is of the gun with the remixed grip and the remaining pics are with the original grip. The main model was sourced from - https://www.myminifactory.com/object/hellboy-s-handgun-good-samaritan-4945 I remixed and resized muckychris's grip and logo found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:241861 The model is sliced for printing on smaller printers and did not require any supports. I used 15% infill and printed the model using Hatchbox 1.75mm PLA. Missing trigger assembly has been added. If you are planning on using the shield grip rather than the original grip, you will need to cut the grip key off of the trigger assembly.

comments.text:

thanks - danny
